FULL TITLE : DISAGREEMENT WITH PLAN TO LOWER THE AGE OF CRIMINAL RESPONSIBILITY OF CHILDREN
SHORT TITLE : Youth Offenders
ABSTRACT : As a child rights advocate, Rep. Brosas spoke on the issue of lowering the age of criminal responsibility wherein she discussed the economic aspect and social behavior of youth offenders. As she cited the position of the Psychological Association of the Philippines, the SalinLahi Alliance for Children’s Concern, and the Philippine Action for Youth Offenders, she pointed out that lowering the age of criminal responsibility to nine years old has no basis and would be making the situation worse and would create a far bleaker and darker future for the generations to come. She stressed that youth offenders should be looked at as victims and not as criminals. As such and as the Philippines is a signatory to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, Rep. Brosas enjoined her colleagues to probe into the implementation of the Juvenile Justice and Welfare Act and to help strengthen the government’s capacity to respond to the problem of youth offenders by establishing more halfway homes and empowering social workers on the ground before putting the blame on the children themselves. (SOURCE: House Journal No.5,pp.50-51)
